In Surah Al-A’laa verse 6, Allah assures the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) with the words: **“Sanuqri’uka fa la tansa”** (We will make you recite, so you will not forget). This verse, revealed during the early Meccan period, addresses a profound human concern—the fear of forgetting divine revelation. Historical accounts note that the Prophet, upon receiving revelations, would sometimes repeat verses aloud to commit them to memory, reflecting his deep responsibility to convey Allah’s message accurately. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states in *Nahj al-Balagha*: "The Quran was revealed to his heart as a flowing spring, not as ink on parchment. It also serves as a reminder that spiritual responsibilities, though daunting, are met with divine support—a message of hope and perseverance in both faith and daily life.
6.layer2short: In Surah Al-A'laa (87:6), Allah declares, *"We will make you recite, [O Muhammad], and you will not forget,"* a verse that Shia exegetes have analyzed through theological and ontological lenses. Classical commentators such as Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* emphasize that this divine assurance addresses both the Prophet’s human nature and his divinely protected (*ma'sum*) status. Tabrisi notes that the verse responds to an implicit anxiety in the Prophet (peace be upon him and his progeny) about retaining revelation, affirming that Allah’s empowerment transcends ordinary human limitations. This aligns with the Shia doctrine of *‘ismah* (infallibility), wherein prophets and Imams are shielded by Allah from error in receiving, preserving, and conveying revelation.

7.layer1:
This verse from Surah Al-A'laa establishes two profound truths central to Islamic belief: Allah’s absolute authority over all outcomes and His complete knowledge of every aspect of existence. The phrase *إِلَّا مَا شَآءَ ٱللَّهُ* ("Except what Allah should will") appears in a context where the Quran reminds humanity of its limited control, emphasizing that even human efforts—whether memorizing divine revelations, achieving goals, or avoiding errors—are ultimately subject to divine permission. Scholars like Allamah Tabatabai explain in *Al-Mizan* that this exception clause balances human responsibility with divine sovereignty, affirming that while people must strive, results depend on Allah’s wisdom. Historically, this Meccan verse countered pre-Islamic fatalism by teaching that Allah’s will governs the universe, not random chance or human arrogance.

The terms *ٱلْجَهْرَ* (al-jahr, "what is declared") and *مَا يَخْفَىٰ* (ma yakhfa, "what is hidden") encompass all realities—visible actions, secret thoughts, and even unspoken intentions. This comprehensive knowledge calls believers to sincerity in worship and integrity in conduct, knowing nothing escapes Allah’s awareness. For contemporary Muslims, this verse nurtures *tawakkul* (trust in Allah) amid life’s uncertainties. It encourages humility in success ("This was only by Allah’s will") and patience in hardship, recognizing that divine wisdom may differ from our immediate desires. Practically, it invites self-reflection: Are our hidden intentions as pure as our outward deeds? Do we acknowledge Allah’s role in our achievements? By internalizing this verse, Muslims cultivate both spiritual mindfulness and ethical consistency, aligning their lives with the recognition that *إِنَّهُۥ يَعْلَمُ*—"Indeed, He knows.
7.layer2:
In Surah Al-A’laa (87:7), the phrase *"Except what Allah should will"* (إِلَّا مَا شَآءَ ٱللَّهُ) has been interpreted by classical Shia exegetes as a profound affirmation of divine sovereignty over revelation and human agency. Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, situates this verse within the broader discourse on prophetic infallibility (*ismah*), noting that the exception clause underscores Allah’s absolute authority to preserve or abrogate aspects of revelation according to His wisdom. The verse, revealed in the context of the Prophet’s (ص) recitation of the Qur’an, emphasizes that while human memory may falter, divine will ensures the integrity of what is essential for guidance. This aligns with the Shia theological principle that prophets and Imams, as inheritors of divine knowledge (*ilm ladunni*), are divinely protected from error in matters of religious transmission.

Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, highlights the verse’s connection to Allah’s omniscience: *"He knows what is declared and what is hidden."* This duality reflects the Shia understanding of *zahir* (apparent) and *batin* (esoteric) dimensions of revelation, with the Imams serving as interpreters of hidden meanings. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (ع) is reported to have linked this verse to the necessity of *ta’wil* (hermeneutical interpretation), asserting that divine knowledge encompasses both the literal text and its deeper, guarded truths accessible only to the purified Ahl al-Bayt (ع). 

Theologically, the verse reinforces the Shia doctrine of *tawhid al-af’al* (oneness of divine agency), wherein all events—including human actions—are ultimately subject to Allah’s will, though not in negation of human responsibility. This balance between predestination and free will (*jabr wa ikhtiyar*) is central to Shia theodicy. Jurisprudentially, the verse’s emphasis on Allah’s all-encompassing knowledge underpins the necessity of adhering to divinely guided authorities (Imams and *fuqaha*) in matters of law and doctrine, ensuring alignment with both manifest and hidden dimensions of the Qur’an. Thus, the verse serves as a nexus of Shia theology, exegesis, and legal theory, affirming divine supremacy while delineating the role of guided human intermediaries.
7.layer3:
In Surah Al-A’laa (87:7), the phrase *“Except what Allah should will”* has inspired rich contemporary Shia discourse, blending theological depth with modern concerns. Scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi emphasize that this verse underscores Allah’s absolute sovereignty while affirming human agency—a balance central to Shia thought. The *“exception”* here is interpreted not as a limitation but as a reminder that divine will harmonizes with human choice, guiding creation toward purpose without negating free will. This aligns with the Shia concept of *bada’* (divine revision), where Allah’s wisdom adapts to evolving human contexts, offering hope amid life’s unpredictability.  

Modern scientific parallels emerge in quantum physics, where indeterminacy at subatomic levels coexists with observable laws—a metaphor for divine knowledge encompassing both manifest (*al-jahr*) and hidden (*al-khafa*) realities. Philosophers like Dr. Mostafa Malekian link this to existential humility: just as science grapples with the unknown, humans must acknowledge the limits of their perception while trusting Allah’s omniscience.  

Socially, the verse speaks to contemporary anxieties—climate crises, AI ethics, or systemic inequality—by affirming that ultimate authority lies with Allah, urging believers to act justly while surrendering outcomes to divine wisdom. It also critiques surveillance capitalism, reminding us that Allah’s knowledge transcends digital tracking, calling for integrity in public and private spheres.  

Interfaith dialogues find common ground here: like Jewish *hashgacha pratit* (divine providence) or Christian teachings on God’s will, this verse invites multicultural reflection on humility and trust. Scholar Reza Shah-Kazemi notes that such shared themes can bridge divides in pluralistic societies.  

Ultimately, this verse challenges modern believers to navigate uncertainty with faith-driven action—a timeless message revitalized for today’s complexities.
7.layer4:
In the luminous verse of Surah Al-A'laa (87:7), Allah’s exception, "Except what Allah should will," unveils a profound truth about the interplay between divine decree and human agency. The Ahlul Bayt (عليهم السلام) taught that this phrase is a key to understanding the balance between submission to Allah’s will and the responsibility of spiritual striving. Imam Ja’far al-Sadiq (عليه السلام) explained, "Allah’s will is the ultimate authority, but His will manifests through the channels of His mercy—the Imams of guidance." This signifies that while human efforts are essential, they are enveloped within the encompassing knowledge and wisdom of Allah, Who knows both the "declared and hidden" aspects of creation.  

The Imams emphasized that recognizing Allah’s will necessitates recognizing the *Wilayah* (divine guardianship) of the Ahlul Bayt. In a hadith, Imam Ali (عليه السلام) stated, "He who claims to submit to Allah’s will without loving us is like one who seeks shade without a tree." This love and allegiance to the Imams align the believer’s heart with the hidden and manifest dimensions of divine wisdom. Lady Fatimah (عليها السلام) illustrated this in her sermon, stating, "Allah made His will a light that guides to His pleasure," implying that true alignment with divine will is inseparable from obedience to the purified guides.  

Practically, this verse invites believers to cultivate *tawakkul* (trust in Allah) while actively seeking nearness to the Ahlul Bayt. Imam al-Baqir (عليه السلام) taught, "When you act, act with certainty that Allah’s will prevails, but let your actions be adorned with the love of Muhammad and his family." This means supplicating for divine alignment, studying the Imams’ teachings, and embracing patience in trials as manifestations of Allah’s hidden wisdom. By anchoring oneself in *Imamah*, the believer navigates life’s uncertainties with the assurance that both the seen and unseen are under the care of the All-Knowing.

7.layer5:
The verse’s phrase *“Except what Allah should will”* has drawn nuanced interpretations across traditions. Both Shia and Sunni scholars agree that the verse affirms divine omnipotence and omniscience, emphasizing Allah’s absolute authority over all matters, including human actions and the preservation of revelation. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) concur that the verse underscores Allah’s knowledge of both manifest and hidden realities, aligning with the Quranic theme of divine transcendence. Ibn Kathir and Al-Tabtabai further highlight its connection to the Prophet’s role in receiving and conveying revelation, noting that divine will supersedes human limitations.  

A key divergence arises in contextualizing the verse’s reference to prophetic forgetfulness. Sunni exegetes like Al-Qurtubi and Al-Razi interpret the exception clause as addressing scenarios where the Prophet might forget certain Quranic verses, except those Allah wills to preserve—a view supported by Sunni hadith literature. In contrast, Shia scholars such as Al-Qummi and Al-Tusi, drawing on the doctrine of *ismah* (prophetic infallibility), reject the notion of forgetfulness in matters of revelation. Al-Tabtabai argues that the verse instead refers to Allah’s selective abrogation (*naskh*) of rulings or verses, with the exception clause affirming divine control over legislative changes.  

These differences reflect broader theological frameworks: Sunni interpretations often integrate narrations about the Prophet’s human experiences, while Shia exegesis prioritizes the infallibility of divine messengers and their successors (*Ahl al-Bayt*). Historically, Shia emphasis on *ismah* emerged alongside doctrinal developments surrounding the Imamate, whereas Sunni reliance on hadith-based contextualization reflects their methodological adherence to prophetic tradition (*sunna*).  

Both traditions agree that the verse reinforces Allah’s sovereignty, but their distinct hermeneutical priorities shape practical understandings of revelation’s preservation and the Prophet’s role. Such variations illustrate how theological principles and historical contexts inform exegetical diversity while maintaining shared reverence for Quranic authority.

یہ اختلافات وسیع تر مذہبی فریم ورک کی عکاسی کرتے ہیں: سنی تشریحات اکثر نبی of کے انسانی تجربات کے بارے میں بیانات کو مربوط کرتی ہیں ، جبکہ شیعہ الہی میسینجرز اور ان کے جانشینوں کی عدم استحکام کو ترجیح دیتے ہیں (*AHL ALBYT*)۔ تاریخی طور پر ، شیعہ پر زور*عثمہ*امامیٹ کے آس پاس کے نظریاتی پیشرفتوں کے ساتھ سامنے آیا ہے ، جبکہ حدیث پر مبنی سیاق و سباق پر سنی انحصار ان کے طریقہ کار کی پیشن گوئی کی روایت (*سنت*) پر عمل پیرا ہونے کی عکاسی کرتا ہے۔

Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, situates this verse within the broader discourse on prophetic infallibility (*ismah*), noting that the exception clause underscores Allah’s absolute authority to preserve or abrogate aspects of revelation according to His wisdom. The verse, revealed in the context of the Prophet’s (ص) recitation of the Qur’an, emphasizes that while human memory may falter, divine will ensures the integrity of what is essential for guidance. This aligns with the Shia theological principle that prophets and Imams, as inheritors of divine knowledge (*ilm ladunni*), are divinely protected from error in matters of religious transmission.

8.layer1:
In Surah Al-A'laa, verse 8, Allah assures the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him): *"Wa nuyassiruka lil-yusra"*—"And We will ease you toward ease." This verse, revealed during the challenging Meccan period, carries profound reassurance. The Prophet faced intense opposition while conveying Islam’s message, and this divine promise affirmed that Allah would simplify his path, aligning it with *yusra* (ease)—a term rooted in the Arabic *yasara* (to make easy). The repetition of the root *Y-S-R* emphasizes Allah’s unwavering support, transforming difficulty into manageable steps through divine grace.  

Shia tafsir, as explained by scholars like Allama Tabatabai, highlights this verse as a universal principle: Allah facilitates the journey of those committed to truth. Historically, this promise manifested not only in the Prophet’s resilience but also in the continuity of guidance through the Ahlul Bayt, who carried forward this "ease" by preserving and interpreting Islam’s teachings. The verse underscores *tawfiq*—divine enablement—where sincerity and effort attract Allah’s assistance, even amid trials.  

For contemporary Muslims, this verse offers both comfort and direction. It teaches that ease is not the absence of hardship but the presence of Allah’s support in navigating challenges. Whether facing personal struggles, societal pressures, or spiritual doubts, believers are reminded to trust in *tawakkul* (reliance on Allah) while actively striving for righteousness. Practically, this means approaching obligations—prayer, ethical choices, community service—with the confidence that Allah simplifies what aligns with higher purpose. By internalizing this Quranic principle, Muslims cultivate patience, hope, and gratitude, recognizing that every step toward truth is met with divine grace.
8.layer2:
In Surah Al-A'laa (87:8), Allah declares, *"And We will ease you toward ease,"* a verse rich in theological and practical implications within Shia exegesis. Classical commentators emphasize this as a divine assurance to the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his progeny), affirming Allah’s unwavering support in fulfilling his mission. Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, interprets "ease" (*yusra*) as the facilitation of the Prophet’s path toward spiritual and worldly success, encompassing both the dissemination of Islam and the triumph of truth. This aligns with the Shia understanding of divine providence (*lutf*)—a principle asserting Allah’s grace in guiding creation toward perfection through chosen representatives.

Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, expands this by contextualizing the verse within the Quran’s broader thematic contrast between "ease" (*yusra*) and "hardship" (*usra*). He posits that the repetition of the root *y-s-r* underscores Allah’s commitment to removing obstacles from the Prophet’s path, enabling him to uphold *tawhid* (monotheism) and establish justice. Shia theology uniquely links this divine assistance to the Prophet’s role as the progenitor of the *Ahl al-Bayt*, whose divinely ordained leadership (*imamah*) perpetuates this "ease" for humanity. The verse thus implicitly validates the necessity of following the Imams, who embody the continuation of prophetic guidance.

Jurisprudentially, this verse reinforces the Shia principle of *taysir* (facilitation) in religious practice, reflecting Allah’s mercy in legislation. It assures believers that adherence to divine law—anchored in the teachings of the Prophet and his Household—is inherently aligned with human nature (*fitra*), avoiding undue hardship. Classical scholars like Shaykh al-Tusi further correlate this "ease" to the spiritual and intellectual clarity provided by the Imams, who illuminate the path of righteousness amid life’s complexities. In essence, the verse encapsulates the Shia worldview of divine-human synergy, where Allah’s grace and human agency coalesce through prophetic and imamic guidance.
8.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-A’laa’s declaration “We will ease you toward ease” (87:8) is interpreted as a divine promise of empowerment through alignment with transcendent purpose. Ayatollah Nasir Makarim Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, frames this as Allah’s commitment to harmonizing human potential with cosmic wisdom—a dynamic interplay between effort and grace. Modern scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali emphasize that this “ease” isn’t passive comfort but a cultivated capacity to navigate complexity through spiritual resilience and ethical clarity, resonating with psychological concepts like post-traumatic growth.  

Neuroscientific insights into neuroplasticity—how focused intention rewires the brain—complement this view, suggesting that sustained spiritual practice (dhikr, prayer, service) aligns believers with the “path of ease” by fostering mental adaptability. Socially, scholars like Sayyida Fatima Mashhour link the verse to contemporary struggles for justice, arguing that systemic inequities—from climate crises to economic disparity—require communities to embody this “ease” through collective action rooted in trust (tawakkul) rather than despair.  

Interfaith dialogues highlight parallels: Buddhist teachings on “right effort” and Christian mysticism’s “divine surrender” both echo the balance between human agency and transcendent support. In multicultural contexts, the verse invites reimagining “ease” as solidarity across differences—a theme amplified by scholars like Reza Shah-Kazemi, who frames it as a call to dissolve ideological rigidities. Ultimately, this verse challenges modern believers to reframe adversity as a gateway to purposeful flow, where struggle becomes sacred scaffolding for individual and societal transformation.
8.layer4:
The verse "And We will ease you toward ease" (87:8) is illuminated by the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) as a profound promise of divine support for those who align their hearts and actions with the path of wilayah (divine guardianship). Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states in *Nahjul Balagha*: "Allah has made the easy path a light for those who seek Him, and a fortress for those who hold fast to His rope." This "ease" is not worldly comfort but the spiritual clarity attained through submission to Allah’s chosen guides.  

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explains this verse in light of Imamah: "The ease mentioned here is the recognition of the Imam, for whoever knows his Imam walks upon the illuminated path, free from the darkness of doubt." The Ahlul Bayt teach that true ease arises from surrendering to divine authority, allowing the believer to transcend worldly struggles through the transformative power of faith. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) emphasized this in her sermon: "The Quran guides to that which is most easing, for the soul finds rest only in obedience to the Merciful."  

Practically, this verse invites believers to trust Allah’s wisdom during trials, knowing He facilitates growth through challenges. Imam Zain al-Abideen (peace be upon him) advises in *Sahifa Sajjadiyya*: "Seek ease through gratitude in hardship, for ease follows every difficulty by His decree." Spiritual ease is thus attained by embracing the Imam’s guidance, performing obligatory acts with sincerity, and viewing life’s tests as opportunities to strengthen reliance on Allah.  

In essence, the "ease" promised is the serenity of a heart anchored in wilayah, where every step toward Allah is met with His boundless grace. As Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught: "Hold fast to the rope of Allah collectively, and you will be led to the ease of His mercy.

8.layer5:
The interpretation of Surah Al-A'laa 8 ("And We will ease you toward ease") reveals significant convergences between Shia and Sunni scholarly traditions, alongside nuanced divergences rooted in theological frameworks. Both traditions broadly agree that the verse reassures the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) of divine facilitation in his mission, emphasizing Allah’s support in overcoming challenges. Sunni commentators like Ibn Kathir (*Tafsir al-Quran al-Azim*) and Shia scholars such as Tabatabai (*Al-Mizan*) concur that this "ease" encompasses spiritual guidance, moral fortitude, and the eventual success of Islam’s message. Al-Tabari (*Jami al-Bayan*) and Al-Tusi (*At-Tibyan*) both highlight linguistic parallels between this verse and Quranic assurances of divine help for righteous believers, framing it as a universal principle of Allah’s mercy.  

Key differences emerge in contextual extensions. Shia exegetes, particularly Al-Qummi (*Tafsir al-Qummi*) and Tabrisi (*Majma al-Bayan*), often link this "ease" to the Prophet’s role in establishing the *Ahl al-Bayt* as enduring guides, interpreting the verse as implicitly affirming the Imamate’s necessity for continued divine guidance. In contrast, Sunni scholars like Al-Qurtubi (*Al-Jami li-Ahkam*) and Al-Razi (*Mafatih al-Ghayb*) focus on the verse’s immediate application to the Prophet’s life, emphasizing his personal resilience and the Quran’s gradual revelation as manifestations of this ease.  

These interpretations influence religious perspectives: Shia thought underscores the Imam’s divinely facilitated role in preserving teachings, while Sunni discourse emphasizes communal adherence to prophetic precedent (*sunnah*). Historically, these divergences reflect distinct epistemological priorities—Shia theology’s emphasis on hereditary spiritual authority versus Sunni emphasis on textual and communal transmission. Both traditions, however, unite in viewing the verse as a testament to Allah’s unwavering support for His messengers and their followers.

" This verse, revealed during the challenging Meccan period, carries profound reassurance. The Prophet faced intense opposition while conveying Islam’s message, and this divine promise affirmed that Allah would simplify his path, aligning it with *yusra* (ease)—a term rooted in the Arabic *yasara* (to make easy). By internalizing this Quranic principle, Muslims cultivate patience, hope, and gratitude, recognizing that every step toward truth is met with divine grace.
8.layer2short: In Surah Al-A'laa (87:8), Allah declares, *"And We will ease you toward ease,"* a verse rich in theological and practical implications within Shia exegesis. Classical commentators emphasize this as a divine assurance to the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his progeny), affirming Allah’s unwavering support in fulfilling his mission. Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, interprets "ease" (*yusra*) as the facilitation of the Prophet’s path toward spiritual and worldly success, encompassing both the dissemination of Islam and the triumph of truth. This aligns with the Shia understanding of divine providence (*lutf*)—a principle asserting Allah’s grace in guiding creation toward perfection through chosen representatives.

9.layer1:
The verse "فَذَكِّرْ إِن نَّفَعَتِ ٱلذِّكْرَىٰ" (So remind, if the reminder should benefit) from Surah Al-A'laa carries profound guidance for both the Prophet Muhammad (saw) and the Ummah. At its core, it instructs believers to share divine wisdom and moral reminders *when such guidance can positively impact others*. The Arabic term *dhakkir* (remind) derives from *dhikr*, which signifies remembrance of Allah’s truth and warnings. Here, the instruction is conditional: the duty to advise is tied to receptivity, emphasising wisdom over rigid insistence. This aligns with Shia teachings on *amr bil-ma’ruf* (enjoining good), which prioritises discernment and compassion in guiding others.

Historically, this verse reflects the challenges faced by the Prophet (saw) in Mecca, where many rejected his message. Classical Shia tafsir, such as Sheikh Tabarsi’s *Majma al-Bayan*, notes that Allah directed the Prophet to focus his efforts on those open to transformation, avoiding wasted energy on hardened hearts. The Ahlul Bayt (as) exemplified this principle: Imam Ali (as) emphasised tailoring guidance to people’s capacity, while Imam Sadiq (as) taught that effective reminders must resonate with the listener’s state of mind.

In modern life, this verse urges Muslims to balance conviction with practicality. It encourages sharing Islamic teachings—whether through words, actions, or social advocacy—where there is genuine potential for positive change, while avoiding confrontational approaches that alienate others. Practically, this might mean focusing on nurturing understanding within families, communities, or public discourse when receptivity exists. It also invites self-reflection: before advising others, one must ensure their own actions align with the *dhikra* they share, embodying the Quranic values they seek to promote. Ultimately, the verse underscores the timeless Shia ethic of compassionate, purposeful outreach—rooted in the luminous example of the Prophet and his purified progeny.
9.layer2:
In Surah Al-A'laa (87:9), the Divine command *"So remind, if the reminder should benefit"* establishes a profound principle of prophetic and Imamic guidance central to Shia theology. Classical commentators emphasize this verse's conditional phrasing as a directive for *targeted spiritual instruction* contingent upon receptivity—a theme recurrent in the teachings of the Ahl al-Bayt. Al-Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* notes that the verse does not restrict the obligation of *tadhkir* (reminding) but rather qualifies its application, aligning with the Prophetic sunna of "speaking to people according to their level of understanding" (as narrated from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq). This reflects the Shia principle of *al-taqiyya* (prudential concealment) and adaptive pedagogy, where guidance is modulated to maximize benefit.

Al-Tabtabai's *Al-Mizan* expands this into a metaphysical framework: true benefit (*nafa'a*) arises when the reminder synergizes with the innate *fitra* (primordial nature) awakened through the Nur al-Wilaya (Light of Guardianship). The verse thus implicitly affirms the Shia doctrine of *lutf* (divine grace), wherein prophets and Imams are appointed as essential channels for actualizing human potential. The "benefit" condition thereby becomes an ontological criterion—not mere pragmatic utility—rooted in the Qur'anic concept of *tawfiq* (divine enablement).

Jurisprudentially, this verse underpins the Shia understanding of *al-amr bil-ma'ruf* (enjoining good), requiring discernment between *productive admonition* and *futile repetition*. As Imam Ali states in Nahj al-Balagha, "Do not revive knowledge where ignorance suffices." The reminder's efficacy is thus tied to the presence of *qabul* (acceptance), reflecting the Shi'i emphasis on the interplay between divine guidance (*hidaya*) and human agency (*ikhtiyar*). This verse consequently serves as a cornerstone for the ethical and epistemological frameworks governing both individual spiritual practice and the Imams' pedagogical mission.
9.layer3:
In Surah Al-A'laa, verse 9, the Quranic directive *"So remind, if the reminder should benefit"* resonates powerfully in contemporary Shia scholarship as a call to *strategic, compassionate communication* rooted in wisdom. Modern scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarim Shirazi emphasise that this verse underscores the ethical responsibility to tailor guidance to its audience’s receptivity—a principle echoed in Imam Ali’s advice to "speak to people according to their intellects" (Nahj al-Balagha). Today, this intersects with psychological insights on effective messaging: studies in behavioural science affirm that reminders framed empathetically, accounting for cultural and cognitive diversity, foster lasting change.  

Contemporary applications extend to addressing social fragmentation. Scholar Sayed Ammar Nakshawani notes that in an era of information overload, the verse challenges Muslims to prioritise *quality over quantity* in spiritual outreach—focusing on dialogue that heals rather than polarises. This aligns with interfaith efforts where shared ethical values (e.g., climate stewardship, poverty alleviation) become bridges for collective action. For instance, Shia theologians collaborate with ecumenical groups to reframe environmental crises as moral imperatives, invoking Quranic stewardship (khalifa) of Earth.  

Philosophically, the verse critiques performative religiosity, urging believers to assess impact over intent. In contexts like mental health advocacy, scholars integrate Islamic teachings with trauma-informed care, recognising that reminders of divine mercy must be coupled with actionable support for those struggling. The conditional "if" here becomes a safeguard against spiritual burnout, encouraging adaptive methods in education and activism.  

Ultimately, this verse invites a balance between timeless truth and temporal sensitivity—a vision where faith speaks not only to eternity but to the urgent, evolving needs of humanity.
9.layer4:
The verse "So remind, if the reminder should benefit" (87:9) is illuminated by the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) as a profound call to divine guidance rooted in the recognition of Wilayah (spiritual guardianship). Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states, "Remembrance is a light for the one who heeds it, but a burden for the heedless," emphasizing that true benefit arises only when hearts are receptive to the luminous guidance of Allah’s chosen representatives. The Holy Prophet (peace be upon him and his family) taught that reminders must be delivered with wisdom, saying, "Speak to people according to their understanding," a principle echoed by Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him), who explained that "the reminder benefits only those whose hearts Allah has opened to the love of the Ahlul Bayt."

This verse is intrinsically tied to the concept of Imamah, as the Imams are the living embodiment of divine remembrance. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) declared in her famous sermon, "We are the remembrance of Allah, and through us, guidance is sought." The "reminder" here transcends mere words; it is the eternal light of the Imams, who preserve and transmit the Quran’s esoteric truths. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught that true tadhkir (reminder) awakens the soul to its innate recognition of Wilayah, stating, "The hearts of the believers yearn for us, for we are the remembrance of the Merciful."

Practically, this verse urges believers to align their intentions with the recognition of divine authority. Spiritual benefit flows from submitting to the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings, engaging in daily dhikr (remembrance) of Allah through their intercession, and embodying their ethical example. Imam al-Baqir (peace be upon him) advised, "Remind yourselves of Allah by loving us, for our love is the foundation of faith." Thus, the "benefit" of reminder manifests as a heart illuminated by the love of the Imams, transforming ritual into reality and knowledge into luminous action.

یہ آیت امامہ کے تصور سے اندرونی طور پر منسلک ہے ، کیونکہ امام الہی یادوں کا زندہ مجسمہ ہیں۔ لیڈی فاطمہ (ان پر امن) نے اپنے مشہور خطبہ میں اعلان کیا ، "ہم اللہ کی یاد ہیں ، اور ہمارے ذریعہ رہنمائی کی طلب کی گئی ہے۔" یہاں "یاد دہانی" محض الفاظ سے ماورا ہے۔ یہ اماموں کی ابدی روشنی ہے ، جو قرآن کی باطنی سچائیوں کو محفوظ اور منتقل کرتی ہے۔ امام علی (اس پر امن ہے) نے یہ سکھایا کہ سچے تدکیر (یاد دہانی) نے روح کو ولایہ کی اپنی فطری پہچان کے لئے بیدار کیا ، "مومنین کے دل ہمارے لئے ترس رہے ہیں ، کیوں کہ ہم مہربانوں کی یاد ہیں۔"

عملی طور پر ، یہ آیت مومنین سے الہی اتھارٹی کی پہچان کے ساتھ اپنے ارادوں کو سیدھ میں کرنے کی تاکید کرتی ہے۔ روحانی فائدہ اہل بیت کی تعلیمات کو پیش کرنے ، ان کی شفاعت کے ذریعہ اللہ کے روزانہ کی دھک (یاد) میں شامل ہونے اور ان کی اخلاقی مثال کو مجسم بنانے سے بہتا ہے۔ امام البقیر (اس پر امن) نے مشورہ دیا ، "ہم سے پیار کرکے اپنے آپ کو اللہ کی یاد دلائیں ، کیونکہ ہماری محبت ایمان کی بنیاد ہے۔" اس طرح ، یاد دہانی کا "فائدہ" ایک دل کے طور پر ظاہر ہوتا ہے جو اماموں کی محبت سے روشن ہوتا ہے ، اور رسم کو حقیقت اور علم میں برائٹ عمل میں تبدیل کرتا ہے۔
9.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Al-A'laa 9 ("So remind, if the reminder should benefit"), Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on core ethical principles while diverging in theological emphasis. Both traditions agree the verse establishes a conditional prophetic duty to offer guidance where receptivity exists, as noted by Sunni scholar Al-Tabari (Jami al-Bayan) and Shia authority Al-Tabrisi (Majma al-Bayan). They share the view that divine wisdom dictates tailored communication, with Ibn Kathir (Tafsir al-Quran al-Azim) emphasizing the Prophet’s obligation to prioritize receptive audiences, while Al-Tusi (At-Tibyan) underscores the necessity of aligning reminders with intellectual and spiritual readiness.

A key divergence emerges in contextualizing the "benefit" (nafaʿat) condition. Sunni commentators like Al-Qurtubi (Al-Jami li-Ahkam) frame this as a general principle for all believers, stressing communal responsibility in daʿwah provided there is potential for positive impact. In contrast, Shia exegetes such as Al-Tabatabai (Al-Mizan) link the verse’s efficacy to the ontological role of divinely appointed guides (Ahl al-Bayt), arguing that true benefit manifests through allegiance to Imamic wisdom. Al-Qummi’s tafsir extends this, positing that reminders attain full effectiveness only when conveyed through the Imams’ purified lineage.

These interpretations influence religious practice: Sunni thought encourages broad-based preaching with optimism about guidance’s potential, while Shia tradition emphasizes the necessity of seeking and transmitting knowledge through authorized spiritual authorities. The divergence stems from distinct theological frameworks regarding post-prophetic leadership – Sunni emphasis on communal interpretive effort (ijtihad) versus Shia focus on preserved, infallible guidance (isma). Al-Razi (Mafatih al-Ghayb) acknowledges the Sunni position’s flexibility, whereas Shia sources root their view in the Quranic paradigm of successive divine guides (5:55, 13:7). Both traditions ultimately affirm the verse’s call to purposeful, context-sensitive guidance while grounding their approaches in respective epistemological foundations.

سورہ الاولا 9 کی ترجمانی کرتے ہوئے ("تو یاد دلائیں ، اگر یاد دہانی کو فائدہ اٹھانا چاہئے") ، شیعہ اور سنی نے مذہبی زور سے ہٹتے ہوئے بنیادی اخلاقی اصولوں پر تبادلہ خیال کیا۔ دونوں روایات اس سے متفق ہیں کہ آیت اس رہنمائی کی پیش کش کے لئے ایک مشروط پیشن گوئی کا فرض قائم کرتی ہے جہاں استقبالیہ موجود ہے ، جیسا کہ سنی اسکالر التباری (جمی البیان) اور شیعہ اتھارٹی الاتبریسی (مجمہ البیان) نے نوٹ کیا ہے۔ وہ اس نظریہ کو بانٹتے ہیں کہ خدائی حکمت کے مطابق مواصلات کا حکم دیا گیا ہے ، جس میں ابن کتھیر (طافسیر القوران الازیم) کے ساتھ قبول کرنے والے سامعین کو ترجیح دینے کے نبی کی ذمہ داری پر زور دیا گیا ہے ، جبکہ التوسی (ایٹ تبیان) دانشورانہ اور روحانی تیاری کے ساتھ جکڑے ہوئے یاد دہانیوں کی ضرورت پر زور دیتا ہے۔

"فوائد" (نفائت) کی حالت کو سیاق و سباق بنانے میں ایک اہم موڑ ابھرتا ہے۔ سنی مبصرین جیسے القوروبی (الجامی لی احکم) تمام مومنین کے لئے عام اصول کے طور پر اس کا فریم کرتے ہیں ، اور داؤہ میں فرقہ وارانہ ذمہ داری پر زور دیتے ہیں بشرطیکہ اس کے مثبت اثرات کی صلاحیت موجود ہو۔ اس کے برعکس ، شیعہ التباطابائی (المزان) جیسے استثنیٰ کی آیت کی افادیت کو خدائی طور پر مقرر کردہ ہدایت نامہ (اے ایچ ایل ال بیت) کے آنٹولوجیکل کردار سے جوڑتے ہیں ، اور یہ استدلال کرتے ہیں کہ حقیقی فائدہ امامک حکمت سے وفاداری کے ذریعہ ظاہر ہوتا ہے۔ القومی کے طافسیر نے اس میں توسیع کی ، اس بات کی نشاندہی کرتے ہوئے کہ یاد دہانیوں کو صرف اس وقت مکمل تاثیر حاصل ہوتی ہے جب اماموں کے پاک نسب کے ذریعے پہنچایا جاتا ہے۔

یہ تشریحات مذہبی رواج کو متاثر کرتی ہیں: سنی سوچ رہنمائی کی صلاحیت کے بارے میں امید کے ساتھ وسیع البنیاد تبلیغ کی حوصلہ افزائی کرتی ہے ، جبکہ شیعہ روایت مجاز روحانی حکام کے ذریعہ علم کی تلاش اور منتقل کرنے کی ضرورت پر زور دیتی ہے۔ یہ موڑ بعد کے پروفیوٹک قیادت کے حوالے سے الگ الگ مذہبی فریم ورک سے پیدا ہوتا ہے-فرقہ وارانہ تشریحی کوششوں پر سنی پر زور (IJTiHad) بمقابلہ شیعہ محفوظ ، ناقابل تسخیر رہنمائی (ISMA) پر توجہ مرکوز کرتا ہے۔ العمجی (مافاتیہ الغیب) نے سنی پوزیشن کی لچک کو تسلیم کیا ، جبکہ شیعہ کے ذرائع نے یکے بعد دیگرے الہی گائیڈز (5:55 ، 13: 7) کے قرآنی تمثیل میں اپنے نظریہ کو جڑ سے اکھاڑ دیا۔ دونوں روایات بالآخر آیت کی کال کو بامقصد ، سیاق و سباق سے متعلق حساس رہنمائی کی تصدیق کرتی ہیں جبکہ متعلقہ علمی بنیادوں میں ان کے نقطہ نظر کو بنیاد بناتی ہیں۔
9.summary: Sheikh Tabrisi in Majma al-Bayan notes that this verse does not restrict the obligation of *tadhkir* (reminding) but rather qualifies its application, aligning with the Prophetic sunna of "speaking to people according to their level of understanding" (as narrated from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq). The verse "فَذَكِّرْ إِن نَّفَعَتِ ٱلذِّكْرَىٰ" (So remind, if the reminder should benefit) from Surah Al-A'laa carries profound guidance for both the Prophet Muhammad (saw) and the Ummah. At its core, it instructs believers to share divine wisdom and moral reminders *when such guidance can positively impact others*. The Arabic term *dhakkir* (remind) derives from *dhikr*, which signifies remembrance of Allah’s truth and warnings. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states, "Remembrance is a light for the one who heeds it, but a burden for the heedless," emphasizing that true benefit arises only when hearts are receptive to the luminous guidance of Allah’s chosen representatives. Ultimately, the verse underscores the timeless Shia ethic of compassionate, purposeful outreach—rooted in the luminous example of the Prophet and his purified progeny.
9.layer2short: In Surah Al-A'laa (87:9), the Divine command *"So remind, if the reminder should benefit"* establishes a profound principle of prophetic and Imamic guidance central to Shia theology. Classical commentators emphasize this verse's conditional phrasing as a directive for *targeted spiritual instruction* contingent upon receptivity—a theme recurrent in the teachings of the Ahl al-Bayt. Al-Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* notes that the verse does not restrict the obligation of *tadhkir* (reminding) but rather qualifies its application, aligning with the Prophetic sunna of "speaking to people according to their level of understanding" (as narrated from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq). This reflects the Shia principle of *al-taqiyya* (prudential concealment) and adaptive pedagogy, where guidance is modulated to maximize benefit.

10.layer1:
The verse "سَيَذَّكَّرُ مَن يَخْشَىٰ" from Surah Al-A'laa carries profound wisdom about spiritual receptivity. At its core, it teaches that true remembrance of divine guidance comes to those who cultivate *khashya* – a reverential awe of Allah that transcends superficial fear. Classical Shia commentators like Allamah Tabatabai explain in *Tafsir al-Mizan* that this "fear" isn’t anxiety, but a conscious awareness of Allah’s majesty that makes one spiritually alert. The verse, revealed during Mecca’s challenging early Islamic period, reassured believers that sincere hearts would always receive divine illumination despite societal opposition.

The key Arabic term *yakhsha* (يَخْشَىٰ) derives from *khashya*, denoting a profound, love-infused reverence distinct from ordinary fright (*khawf*). Its reciprocal *yadhakkaru* (يَذَّكَّرُ) comes from *tadhakkur* – the act of internalizing spiritual reminders. Shia tradition, as noted by scholars like Shaykh Tabarsi in *Majma al-Bayan*, emphasizes that such reminders manifest through the Quran, prophetic teachings, and the guidance of the Ahlul Bayt, who are described as "the firm rope of divine remembrance."

For contemporary Muslims, this verse invites self-reflection: Do we approach faith with this transformative *khashya* that makes us receptive to truth? In an age of distractions, it urges nurturing hearts that actively seek and recognize divine wisdom – whether in Quranic verses, the supplications of Imam Ali Zayn al-Abidin, or ethical challenges. Practically, it means prioritizing sincere *taqwa* over ritual complacency, allowing our awe of Allah to sharpen our moral discernment and openness to learning. As Imam Ali taught, "Knowledge is a shield against errors" – a shield forged through the holy fear that makes us students of eternity.
10.layer2:
In interpreting Surah Al-A'laa (87:10), classical Shia exegetes emphasize the reciprocal relationship between human spiritual preparedness and divine guidance. The verse's declaration that "He who fears [Allah] will be reminded" establishes *khashya* (reverential fear) as the precondition for receiving *tadhkir* (reminder). As Tabrisi elucidates in *Majma al-Bayan*, this "fear" transcends mere dread, encapsulating the Shia concept of *taqwa* — a God-consciousness that combines awe, love, and ethical vigilance. Such individuals, he notes, become vessels for divine illumination through engagement with the Quran and the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt.

Tabatabai's *Al-Mizan* expands this ontologically, framing the "reminder" as an existential grace (*lutf*) granted to souls who actively cultivate receptivity. Drawing from the Imam Jafar al-Sadiq's principle that "Hearts are vessels — the best are those most attentive," he posits that divine guidance operates through causal chains tied to human moral agency. The *tadhkir* thus manifests not only through scriptural recitation but through the living wisdom of the Imams, whose role as "speaking Qurans" (Quran al-Natiq) enables continuous guidance for the spiritually attuned.

This verse also underpins Shia soteriology, where salvation hinges on aligning one's will with divine guardianship (*wilayah*). As articulated in traditions from Imam Ali in *Nahj al-Balagha*, true fear of Allah generates humility that "polishes the heart," making it reflect divine truths. Jurisprudentially, this informs the Shia emphasis on *ijtihad* rooted in Quranic principles and the Imams' teachings, as only the God-fearing scholar (*mujtahid*) can properly derive rulings reflecting divine intent.

Theologically, the verse affirms the Shia view of synergistic grace: while Allah's reminder is universally available, its actualization depends on human ethical striving. This balance between predestination and free will, central to Shia thought, is crystallized here — the "reminder" becomes accessible precisely through the conscious choice to fear He Who is Worthy of all reverence.
10.layer3:
Contemporary Shia scholars interpret Surah Al-A’laa’s declaration, “He who fears [Allah] will be reminded,” as a dynamic interplay between spiritual receptivity and ethical action. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi emphasizes that *khashya* (reverential fear) isn’t paralyzing dread but a conscious awareness aligning human choices with divine wisdom. This “fear” becomes a catalyst for *tadhakkur* (remembrance), a process scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali link to modern mindfulness—awakening the soul to recognize truth amid life’s distractions.  

Neuroscience offers a parallel: studies on neuroplasticity reveal that sustained focus on ethical or spiritual values strengthens neural pathways, making moral intuition more reflexive. The verse thus mirrors the idea that spiritual vigilance—rooted in awe—reshapes cognition, enabling individuals to “remember” their purpose even in chaotic times.  

Socially, this verse speaks to crises of alienation and moral apathy. Scholar Dr. Liyakat Takim connects it to contemporary struggles for justice, noting that those who “fear” Allah’s justice become natural advocates for marginalized communities, from Gaza to the climate-vulnerable Global South. The “reminder” here is both personal and collective—a call to uphold human dignity.  

Interfaith dialogues find resonance here: Buddhist mindfulness, Christian “fear of the Lord,” and secular humanist ethics all value inner awakening as a driver of societal good. In multicultural contexts, the verse invites collaboration, urging diverse communities to harness their reverence for the sacred into shared action against oppression or environmental collapse.  

Ultimately, this verse challenges modern believers: to transform spiritual consciousness into a force for healing our fractured world. As Ayatollah Khamenei has stated, “The true *mutaqeen* [God-conscious] are those who turn remembrance into resistance against tyranny.
10.layer4:
The verse "He who fears [Allah] will be reminded" (87:10) unveils a profound spiritual principle: divine remembrance is a grace bestowed upon hearts purified by *taqwa* (God-consciousness). The Ahlul Bayt (عليهم السلام) taught that this "fear" is not paralyzing dread but a luminous awareness of Allah’s presence that burns away heedlessness. Imam Ali (as) states, *"The fear of Allah is the medicine for your hearts, the light of your blindness, and the cure for your ailments"* (Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 189). This *khashya* (reverent fear) awakens the soul’s capacity to receive guidance through the channels of *Wilayah* (divine guardianship).  

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (as) explains this verse’s inner dimension: *"Only those who tremble before the Majesty of their Lord will be inspired to cling to the Rope of Allah [the Ahlul Bayt], and through them, the veils over the heart are lifted"* (Tafsir al-Qummi). Here, "reminder" transcends mere intellectual recall; it signifies the soul’s revival through attachment to the Imams (عليهم السلام), the living embodiments of Quranic truth. Lady Fatimah (عليها السلام) taught that true *taqwa* is cultivated by "detaching the heart from worldly illusions" (Bihar al-Anwar), creating space for divine light to illuminate the intellect.  

Practically, this verse calls believers to nurture *khashya* through daily *muhasaba* (self-accounting), seeking forgiveness, and immersing in the supplications taught by the Imams. As Imam Ali Zayn al-Abidin (as) prays in Sahifa Sajjadiyya: *"O Allah, make my fear of You a shield against disobedience, and let my yearning for You purify my intentions."* By aligning one’s life with the teachings of the Ma’sumin (عليهم السلام), the heart becomes a mirror reflecting eternal wisdom, transforming every moment into a *dhikr* (remembrance) of the Divine.

عصری مسلمانوں کے لئے ، یہ آیت خود عکاسی کی دعوت دیتی ہے: کیا ہم اس تبدیلی * کھشیا * کے ساتھ ایمان سے رجوع کرتے ہیں جو ہمیں سچائی کے لئے قابل قبول بناتا ہے؟ خلفشار کے دور میں ، یہ ان دلوں کی پرورش کرنے کی تاکید کرتا ہے جو الہی حکمت کو فعال طور پر تلاش کرتے ہیں اور ان کو پہچانتے ہیں-چاہے قرآنی آیات میں ، امام علی زین العبدین کی فراہمی ، یا اخلاقی چیلنجوں کی فراہمی۔ عملی طور پر ، اس کا مطلب یہ ہے کہ رسمی طور پر خوشنودی سے زیادہ مخلص * تقوا * کو ترجیح دی جائے ، اور اللہ سے ہمارے خوف کو ہماری اخلاقی تفہیم اور سیکھنے کے لئے کشادگی کو تیز کرنے کی اجازت دی جائے۔ جیسا کہ امام علی نے سکھایا ، "علم غلطیوں کے خلاف ڈھال ہے" - ایک ڈھال جو مقدس خوف کے ذریعے تیار کی گئی ہے جو ہمیں ابدیت کے طالب علموں کو بناتی ہے۔
10.layer2_urdu:
سورہ الاولا (87:10) کی ترجمانی کرتے ہوئے ، کلاسیکی شیعہ استثنیٰ انسانی روحانی تیاری اور خدائی رہنمائی کے مابین باہمی تعلقات پر زور دیتے ہیں۔ آیت کا یہ اعلان کہ "جو شخص [اللہ] سے ڈرتا ہے اسے یاد دلایا جائے گا" * خشیا * (قابل احترام خوف) کو * تدکیر * (یاد دہانی) وصول کرنے کی پیشگی شرط کے طور پر قائم کرتا ہے۔ جیسا کہ تبریسی *ماجما البیان *میں واضح کرتا ہے ، یہ "خوف" محض خوف سے بالاتر ہے ، جس سے *تقوا *کے شیعہ تصور کو شامل کیا جاتا ہے۔ اس طرح کے افراد ، جو نوٹ کرتے ہیں ، قرآن مجید کے ساتھ مشغولیت اور اہل بائٹ کی تعلیمات کے ذریعہ الہی روشنی کے برتن بن جاتے ہیں۔

تبتابائی کا*المزان*اس کو اونٹولوجیکل طور پر وسعت دیتا ہے ، اور "یاد دہانی" کو ایک وجودی فضل (*lutf*) کے طور پر تیار کرتا ہے جو روحوں کو قبول کرتا ہے جو قبولیت سے استفادہ کرتے ہیں۔ امام جعفر السادق کے اس اصول سے ڈرائنگ کرتے ہوئے کہ "دل برتن ہیں-سب سے زیادہ توجہ دینے والے ہیں ،" انہوں نے کہا ہے کہ الہی رہنمائی انسانی اخلاقی ایجنسی سے منسلک کارآمد زنجیروں کے ذریعے چلتی ہے۔ * تدکیر * اس طرح نہ صرف صحیفاتی تلاوت کے ذریعے بلکہ اماموں کی زندہ حکمت کے ذریعہ ظاہر ہوتا ہے ، جس کا کردار "بولنا قرآن" (قرآن النتق) کے طور پر کردار ادا کرتا ہے جو روحانی طور پر ملحق افراد کے لئے مستقل رہنمائی کے قابل بناتا ہے۔

اس آیت میں شیعہ سوٹریولوجی کو بھی اہمیت دی گئی ہے ، جہاں نجات الہی سرپرستی (*ولیہ*) کے ساتھ کسی کی مرضی کے مطابق کرنے پر منحصر ہے۔ جیسا کہ *ناہج البالاگھا *میں امام علی کی روایات میں بیان کیا گیا ہے ، اللہ کا حقیقی خوف عاجزی پیدا کرتا ہے جو "دل کو پالش کرتا ہے" ، جس سے یہ خدائی سچائیوں کی عکاسی کرتا ہے۔ فقہی طور پر ، اس سے قرآنی اصولوں اور ائوں کی تعلیمات میں جڑے ہوئے*اجتیہاد*پر شیعہ پر زور دینے سے آگاہ ہوتا ہے ، کیونکہ صرف خدا سے بھرا ہوا عالم (*مجتہد*) الہی ارادے کی عکاسی کرنے والے احکام کو صحیح طریقے سے اخذ کرسکتا ہے۔

مذہبی طور پر ، آیت مطابقت پذیری کے فضل کے شیعہ کے نظریہ کی تصدیق کرتی ہے: جبکہ اللہ کی یاد دہانی عالمی طور پر دستیاب ہے ، اس کی حقیقت انسانی اخلاقی جدوجہد پر منحصر ہے۔ پیش گوئی اور آزادانہ مرضی کے مابین یہ توازن ، شیعہ سوچ کے مرکزی خیال ، یہاں کرسٹاللائزڈ ہے - "یاد دہانی" شعوری انتخاب کے ذریعہ خاص طور پر قابل رسائی ہوجاتی ہے تاکہ وہ خوفزدہ ہو جو ہر عقیدت کے قابل ہے۔

نیورو سائنس ایک متوازی پیش کرتا ہے: نیوروپلاسٹیٹی کے مطالعے سے پتہ چلتا ہے کہ اخلاقی یا روحانی اقدار پر مستقل توجہ اعصابی راستوں کو تقویت دیتی ہے ، جس سے اخلاقی انتشار زیادہ اضطراری ہوتا ہے۔ اس طرح آیت اس خیال کی آئینہ دار ہے کہ روحانی چوکسی - حیرت سے جڑی ہوئی ہے۔  

معاشرتی طور پر ، یہ آیت بیگانگی اور اخلاقی بے حسی کے بحرانوں کی بات کرتی ہے۔ اسکالر ڈاکٹر لییاکات تکیم اسے معاصر جدوجہد سے انصاف کے لئے جوڑتے ہیں ، اور یہ کہتے ہوئے کہ جو لوگ اللہ کے انصاف کو "خوفزدہ" کرتے ہیں وہ غزہ سے آب و ہوا سے چلنے والی عالمی سطح پر پسماندہ طبقات کے فطری حامی بن جاتے ہیں۔ یہاں "یاد دہانی" ذاتی اور اجتماعی دونوں ہے۔ یہ انسانی وقار کو برقرار رکھنے کی کال ہے۔  

بین المذاہب مکالمے یہاں گونج پائیں: بدھ مت کی ذہنیت ، عیسائی "خداوند کا خوف" اور سیکولر ہیومنسٹ اخلاقیات معاشرتی بھلائی کے ڈرائیور کی حیثیت سے اندرونی بیداری کی تمام اہمیت۔ کثیر الثقافتی سیاق و سباق میں ، آیت باہمی تعاون کی دعوت دیتی ہے ، جس میں متنوع برادریوں پر زور دیا گیا ہے کہ وہ مقدس کے لئے ان کی عقیدت کو ظلم و ستم یا ماحولیاتی خاتمے کے خلاف مشترکہ کارروائی میں بروئے کار لائے۔

امام جعفر السادق (ع) اس آیت کی اندرونی جہت کی وضاحت کرتے ہیں: * "صرف وہی لوگ جو اپنے رب کی عظمت کے سامنے کانپتے ہیں وہ اللہ [اہل بیت] کی رسی سے چمٹے رہنے کے لئے متاثر ہوں گے ، اور ان کے ذریعہ دل پر پردہ اٹھا لیا گیا ہے" * (طفیر الکوومی)۔ یہاں ، "یاد دہانی" محض دانشورانہ یاد سے ماورا ہے۔ یہ قرآنی سچ کے زندہ مجسموں ، اماموں (علیہم السلام) سے وابستگی کے ذریعہ روح کے حیات نو کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے۔ لیڈی فاطمہ (علیہا السلام) نے سکھایا کہ سچے * تقوا * کو "دل کو دنیاوی وہموں سے الگ کرنے" (بہار الانور) کے ذریعہ کاشت کیا جاتا ہے ، جس سے عقل کو روشن کرنے کے لئے الہی روشنی کے لئے جگہ پیدا ہوتی ہے۔  

عملی طور پر ، اس آیت میں مومنین کو روزانہ * محسابا * (خود حساب کتاب) کے ذریعے * کھاشیا * کی پرورش کرنے ، معافی مانگنے ، اور اماموں کے ذریعہ پڑھائی جانے والی درخواستوں میں غرق کرنے کا مطالبہ کیا گیا ہے۔ جیسا کہ امام علی زین العبدین (ع) ساہفا سججدیہ میں دعا کرتے ہیں: * "اے اللہ ، آپ کے لئے آپ سے خوفزدہ ہوکر نافرمانی کے خلاف ڈھال ڈالے ، اور آپ کے لئے میری تڑپ میرے ارادوں کو پاک کرنے دیں۔" ہر لمحہ الہی کے * دھکر * (یاد) میں۔
10.layer5:
The interpretation of Surah Al-A'laa 10 ("He who fears [Allah] will be reminded") reveals both shared ethical principles and distinct theological emphases across Shia and Sunni traditions. Classical commentators universally agree that the verse underscores the relationship between divine guidance and human receptivity, linking spiritual mindfulness (*khashya*) to the capacity for receiving Allah’s reminders (*tadhkirah*). Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) both emphasize that sincere God-consciousness prepares the heart to internalize Quranic teachings, a view echoed by Ibn Kathir and Al-Tusi, who stress humility as a prerequisite for enlightenment.

Divergences emerge in contextualizing the "reminder." Sunni exegetes like Al-Qurtubi and Al-Razi generally frame this as the Quran itself or prophetic admonitions, focusing on individual moral responsibility. Ibn Kathir ties it to the Prophet’s role as a warner, consistent with Sunni emphasis on Quranic clarity and the Prophet’s finality. Shia sources, however, often extend the concept to include ongoing guidance through the Imams. Al-Qummi and Tabatabai (Al-Mizan) interpret the verse as affirming the necessity of divinely appointed guides (Ahl al-Bayt) who preserve and elucidate revelation—a reflection of the Shia doctrine of Imamah. Al-Tabrisi (Majma al-Bayan) further associates the "reminder" with both the Quran and the purified progeny of the Prophet, integrating it with the Shia principle of *tathir* (purification of the Imams).

These differences stem from distinct theological frameworks developed post-Revelation: Sunni thought prioritizes textual and communal consensus, while Shia theology centers on the Imam’s ontological role as the living *tadhkirah*. Both interpretations, however, converge on the verse’s core ethical imperative: cultivating reverential fear of Allah remains the foundation for spiritual growth across Islamic traditions.

10.summary: In interpreting Surah Al-A'laa (87:10), classical Shia exegetes emphasize the reciprocal relationship between human spiritual preparedness and divine guidance. The verse "سَيَذَّكَّرُ مَن يَخْشَىٰ" from Surah Al-A'laa carries profound wisdom about spiritual receptivity. At its core, it teaches that true remembrance of divine guidance comes to those who cultivate *khashya* – a reverential awe of Allah that transcends superficial fear. Classical Shia commentators like Allamah Tabatabai explain in *Tafsir al-Mizan* that this "fear" isn’t anxiety, but a conscious awareness of Allah’s majesty that makes one spiritually alert. Imam Ali (as) states, *"The fear of Allah is the medicine for your hearts, the light of your blindness, and the cure for your ailments"* (Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 189). This verse invites self-reflection: Do we approach faith with this transformative *khashya* that makes us receptive to truth? In an age of distractions, it urges nurturing hearts that actively seek and recognize divine wisdom – whether in Quranic verses, the supplications of Imam Ali Zayn al-Abidin, or ethical challenges.
10.layer2short: In interpreting Surah Al-A'laa (87:10), classical Shia exegetes emphasize the reciprocal relationship between human spiritual preparedness and divine guidance. The verse's declaration that "He who fears [Allah] will be reminded" establishes *khashya* (reverential fear) as the precondition for receiving *tadhkir* (reminder). As Tabrisi elucidates in *Majma al-Bayan*, this "fear" transcends mere dread, encapsulating the Shia concept of *taqwa* — a God-consciousness that combines awe, love, and ethical vigilance. Such individuals, he notes, become vessels for divine illumination through engagement with the Quran and the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt.

11.layer1:
In Surah Al-A'laa (87:11), Allah states: *"Wa yatajannabuha al-ashqa"* ("But the wretched one will avoid it"), referring to those who turn away from divine guidance and reminders. This verse contrasts with the preceding one (verse 10), which mentions *"al-atqa"* (the God-conscious) who readily heed Allah’s message. The term *"al-ashqa"* (the wretched) derives from *"shaqawah"* (misery), indicating a soul entrenched in spiritual poverty and rebellion. Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, explains that this avoidance isn’t passive indifference but an active rejection of truth due to arrogance or attachment to worldly desires. The *"it"* they avoid refers to Allah’s reminders—the Quran, prophetic teachings, and moral exhortations.

Revealed in Mecca during intense opposition to the Prophet (PBUH), this verse critiques the Quraysh leaders who dismissed his message despite its clarity. Their *"shiqwah"* (wretchedness) stemmed from pride in their social status and rejection of resurrection’s reality. Imam Ali (AS) emphasised in sermons that true wretchedness lies in a heart sealed against truth, as seen in those who mocked revelation.

Today, this verse urges self-reflection: Do we prioritise ego or comfort over Quranic guidance? Modern *"al-ashqa"* might avoid reminders through neglect of prayer, ethical compromises, or dismissing scholarly advice. Conversely, embracing *tadhakkur* (remembrance) through daily Quranic reflection, attending majalis, or seeking knowledge nurtures *taqwa*. The verse’s timeless lesson is that spiritual prosperity requires actively engaging with divine truths—not just hearing them but internalising their wisdom. As Imam Sadiq (AS) taught, "The heart’s corrosion is heedlessness; its polish is remembrance." Avoiding Allah’s reminders isn’t merely a historical error but a daily choice with eternal consequences.
11.layer2:
In Surah Al-A'laa (87:11), the phrase "وَيَتَجَنَّبُهَا ٱلْأَشْقَى" ("But the wretched one will avoid it") presents a profound theological dichotomy between those who heed divine guidance and those who reject it. Classical Shia exegetes, drawing from the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, emphasize that "it" (referenced in the verse) pertains to the "dhikr" or divine reminder mentioned earlier in the surah, understood as the Quranic message and the prophetic legacy upheld by the Imams. Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* explains that the "wretched" (al-ashqa) are those whose souls are corrupted by arrogance and disbelief, causing them to actively evade truth. This evasion is not passive ignorance but a willful rejection rooted in spiritual blindness, as noted by Imam Jafar al-Sadiq in narrations cited by scholars like Al-Kulayni.

Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* expands this concept through the lens of divine justice, asserting that human accountability hinges on one’s response to guidance. The "wretched" are those who, by their own volition, align with misguidance (dalal), thereby manifesting their inherent "shiqawah" (wretchedness) through moral and theological deviations. This aligns with the Shia doctrine of *ikhtiyar* (free will), where individuals bear responsibility for their spiritual trajectory. The verse also subtly underscores the necessity of the Imams’ role as inheritors and interpreters of the "dhikr," as their guidance protects believers from becoming among the "ashqa."

Jurisprudentially, the verse reinforces the obligation to seek and uphold divine truth, a principle foundational to Shia ethics. Avoidance of the "dhikr" is equated with self-destruction, reflecting the broader Islamic tenet that spiritual ruin stems from rejecting revelation. Thus, the verse serves as both a warning and a reaffirmation of the Shia paradigm of divinely ordained leadership (Imamah) as the safeguard against wretchedness.
11.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-A’laa’s verse 11 is often framed as a psychological and social commentary on humanity’s relationship with divine guidance. Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi notes that “the wretched” (*al-ashqa*) here symbolises those who actively distance themselves from moral and spiritual truths, not merely out of ignorance but through a cultivated resistance to self-reflection. This avoidance, argues scholar Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali, mirrors modern society’s “epidemic of distraction”—where hyper-connectivity and consumerism numb ethical awareness, creating a collective *ghaflah* (heedlessness) that deepens existential discontent.

Neuroscientific studies on cognitive dissonance resonate here: when individuals habitually avoid challenging truths, they reinforce neural pathways that prioritise comfort over growth, entrenching cycles of moral stagnation. Socially, this verse critiques systems that normalise inequity or environmental exploitation, as theologian Dr. Liyakat Takim highlights, linking the “wretchedness” of avoidance to structural injustices—from climate denialism to systemic poverty. The verse’s warning extends to interfaith contexts, where dialogue often falters due to avoidance of uncomfortable historical or theological truths, as noted in the work of Shia-Sunni reconciliation advocate Sayyed Ammar Nakshawani.

Philosophically, the verse invites a reevaluation of “freedom” in liberal societies—where autonomy is prized, yet unmoored from transcendent values, it risks becoming a prison of self-interest. For Shia thought leaders like Dr. Rebecca Masterton, this aligns with Imam Ali’s teaching that true liberation lies in submission to divine wisdom. In an era of polarisation, the verse challenges both individuals and communities to confront uncomfortable truths, bridging classical calls for *tazkiyah* (self-purification) with modern imperatives for collective responsibility.
11.layer4:
In Surah Al-A'laa, Allah distinguishes between those who heed divine reminders and "the wretched" who flee from them. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) teach that this wretchedness (shaqāwah) is a spiritual disease rooted in rejecting *Wilayah* (divine guardianship) and the luminous guidance of the Imams. Imam Ali (as) states, "The Quran is Allah’s rope; whoever holds fast to it is guided to Paradise, and whoever abandons it falls into Hell" (*Nahj al-Balagha*). Here, "avoiding the reminder" signifies not merely neglecting Quranic teachings but rejecting the living guidance of the Imams, who are the Quran’s embodied interpreters.  

Imam Sadiq (as) explains, "The wretched is one whose heart is sealed against the love of Ahlul Bayt, for they are the *Dhikr* [Reminder] Allah sent down" (*Tafsir al-Burhan*). This verse thus condemns those who turn away from the Imams’ spiritual authority, choosing arrogance over submission. Lady Fatimah (as) warns in her famed sermon: "The Quran... exposes the corruption in hearts... yet the unjust avoid its light, clinging to the misery of ignorance."  

Spiritually, wretchedness emerges when the soul prioritizes ego over divine truth. Practical protection lies in embracing the Imams’ teachings: reciting the Quran with reflection, seeking nearness to them through supplications like Dua Kumayl, and purifying the heart via repentance. Imam Baqir (as) advises, "Cleanse your hearts through devotion to us, for wretchedness is a veil burned away only by the light of *Ma'rifah* [divine recognition]."  

Ultimately, this verse calls believers to anchor themselves in the Ark of Ahlul Bayt—those who align with their Wilayah thrive, while those who reject it drown in self-inflicted darkness.

سور Surah ال اللہ میں ، اللہ ان لوگوں کے درمیان تمیز کرتا ہے جنہوں نے خدائی یاد دہانیوں اور "بدبخت" پر توجہ دی جو ان سے بھاگتے ہیں۔ اہل بیت (ان پر امن) یہ سکھاتے ہیں کہ یہ بدبختی (شقواہ) ایک روحانی بیماری ہے جو * ولیہ * (خدائی سرپرستی) کو مسترد کرنے اور اماموں کی برائٹ رہنمائی کو مسترد کرتی ہے۔ امام علی (ع) میں کہا گیا ہے ، "قرآن اللہ کی رسی ہے۔ جو بھی اس کو تیز رکھتا ہے اسے جنت کی رہنمائی کی جاتی ہے ، اور جو بھی اسے چھوڑ دیتا ہے وہ جہنم میں پڑ جاتا ہے" (*ناہج البالاگھا*)۔ یہاں ، "یاد دہانی سے گریز کرنا" محض قرآنی تعلیمات کو نظرانداز کرنے کی نشاندہی نہیں کرتا ہے بلکہ ائوں کی رہنمائی کو مسترد نہیں کرتا ہے ، جو قرآن مجید ہیں۔  

امام صادق (ع) کی وضاحت کرتے ہیں ، "بدترین وہ ہے جس کا دل اہل بیت کی محبت کے خلاف مہر لگا ہوا ہے ، کیونکہ وہ*دھکر*[یاد دہانی] اللہ کو بھیجا گیا ہے" (*طافسیر البرہن*)۔ اس طرح یہ آیت ان لوگوں کی مذمت کرتی ہے جو اماموں کے روحانی اتھارٹی سے ہٹ جاتے ہیں ، اور جمع کرانے پر تکبر کا انتخاب کرتے ہیں۔ لیڈی فاطمہ (ع) نے اپنے مشہور خطبہ میں متنبہ کیا: "قرآن مجید ... دلوں میں بدعنوانی کو بے نقاب کرتا ہے ... پھر بھی ناانصافی اس کی روشنی سے بچتی ہے ، اور لاعلمی کی تکلیف سے چمٹ جاتی ہے۔"  

روحانی طور پر ، جب روح الہی سچائی سے زیادہ انا کو ترجیح دیتی ہے تو بدتمیزی ابھرتی ہے۔ عملی تحفظ اماموں کی تعلیمات کو گلے لگانے میں ہے: قرآن کو عکاسی کے ساتھ تلاوت کرنا ، دعا کمیل جیسی التجا کے ذریعہ ان سے قربت کا حصول ، اور توبہ کے ذریعہ دل کو صاف کرنے کے لئے۔ امام بقیر (ع) نے مشورہ دیا ، "ہمارے ساتھ عقیدت کے ذریعے اپنے دلوں کو صاف کریں ، کیونکہ بدترین پن صرف * ماؤرفاہ * [الہی پہچان] کی روشنی سے جلایا ہوا پردہ ہے۔"  

آخر کار ، یہ آیت مومنوں کو اہل بیت کے صندوق میں اپنے آپ کو لنگر انداز کرنے کا مطالبہ کرتی ہے۔ وہ جو اپنے ولیہ کے ساتھ صف بندی کرتے ہیں ، جبکہ اس کو مسترد کرنے والے خود کو اندھیرے میں ڈوبتے ہیں۔
11.layer5:
The verse “But the wretched one will avoid it” (87:11) has drawn nuanced interpretations across Shia and Sunni exegetical traditions, reflecting shared ethical principles and distinct theological emphases. Both traditions agree the verse contrasts those who embrace divine guidance (the “reminder,” *al-dhikr*) and those who reject it due to moral-spiritual wretchedness (*al-ashqā*). Sunni commentators like Tabari and Ibn Kathir emphasize universal moral agency, interpreting “the wretched” as those who willfully neglect Quranic guidance due to arrogance or disbelief, aligning with their broader thematic focus on individual accountability (Ibn Kathir, *Tafsir*). Similarly, Shia scholars such as Tabatabai (*Al-Mizan*) and Tabrisi (*Majma al-Bayan*) stress the intrinsic link between heeding divine reminders and attaining spiritual purity, framing avoidance as a consequence of inner corruption.  

Divergences emerge in contextualizing “the reminder.” Shia exegetes often expand its scope to include the teachings of the Ahl al-Bayt, with Qummi (*Tafsir al-Qummi*) citing traditions that associate avoidance with rejecting the Imams’ authority. This reflects the Shia theological axiom of *imamah* as an extension of divine guidance. Sunni scholars like Qurtubi (*Al-Jami li-Ahkam*) and Razi (*Mafatih al-Ghayb*) limit “the reminder” to the Quran and Prophetic Sunnah, interpreting avoidance as a general rejection of revelation without explicit political or leadership connotations.  

These differences stem from distinct hermeneutical frameworks shaped by early Islamic history. The Shia emphasis on divinely appointed leadership arises from post-Prophetic succession debates, while Sunni exegesis prioritizes communal consensus (*ijma*). Practically, Shia interpretations reinforce adherence to the Imams as embodiments of Quranic truth, whereas Sunni readings emphasize collective adherence to scripture and tradition. Both traditions, however, converge on the ethical imperative to internalize divine guidance, viewing avoidance as a spiritual malady with eschatological consequences. Such analysis underscores how shared Quranic principles are filtered through theological lenses rooted in formative historical experiences.
11.layer5_urdu:
آیت "لیکن بدبخت ایک اس سے گریز کرے گا" (87:11) نے شیعہ اور سنی کی مثال کی روایات میں متنازعہ تشریحات کھینچی ہیں ، جو مشترکہ اخلاقی اصولوں اور الگ الگ مذہبی زوروں کی عکاسی کرتے ہیں۔ دونوں روایات اس سے متفق ہیں کہ آیت ان لوگوں سے متصادم ہے جو خدائی رہنمائی ("یاد دہانی" ،*الدیکر*) کو قبول کرتے ہیں اور جو اخلاقی روحانی بدحالی کی وجہ سے اسے مسترد کرتے ہیں (*الحشق*)۔ تباری اور ابن کتھیر جیسے سنی مبصرین عالمگیر اخلاقی ایجنسی پر زور دیتے ہیں ، اور "بدبخت" کی ترجمانی کرتے ہیں جو انفرادی احتساب (ابن کتھیر ، *طافسیر *) پر ان کی وسیع تر موضوعاتی توجہ کے ساتھ ہم آہنگی سے قرآنی رہنمائی کو نظرانداز کرتے ہیں۔ اسی طرح ، شیعہ اسکالرز جیسے تبتابائی (*المزان*) اور تبریسی (*ماجما البیان*) الہی یاد دہانیوں پر غور کرنے اور روحانی پاکیزگی کے حصول کے درمیان اندرونی روابط پر زور دیتے ہیں ، اندرونی بدعنوانی کے نتیجے میں اجتناب سے بچنا۔  

"یاد دہانی" کے سیاق و سباق میں تغیرات ابھرتے ہیں۔ شیعہ ایگیٹس اکثر اپنے دائرہ کار کو بڑھا سکتے ہیں تاکہ اے ایچ ایل البائٹ کی تعلیمات کو شامل کیا جاسکے ، اس کے ساتھ ، قمی (*طافسیر القومی*) ان روایات کا حوالہ دیتے ہیں جو اماموں کے اتھارٹی کو مسترد کرنے سے گریز کو جوڑتی ہیں۔ یہ الہی رہنمائی کی توسیع کے طور پر * امامہ * کے شیعہ مذہبی محور کی عکاسی کرتا ہے۔ سنی اسکالرز جیسے قربانی (*الجامی لی احکم*) اور رازی (*مافاتیہ الغیب*) "یاد دہانی" کو قرآن اور پیشن گوئی کے لئے محدود کرتے ہیں ، واضح سیاسی یا قیادت کے مفہوم کے بغیر وحی کو عام طور پر مسترد کرنے سے بچنے کی ترجمانی کرتے ہیں۔  

یہ اختلافات ابتدائی اسلامی تاریخ کی شکل میں الگ الگ ہرمینیٹیکل فریم ورک سے پیدا ہوتے ہیں۔ الہی مقرر کردہ قیادت پر شیعہ پر زور دینے کے بعد کے بعد ہونے والے مباحثوں سے پیدا ہوتا ہے ، جبکہ سنی کی اصلاح فرقہ وارانہ اتفاق رائے کو ترجیح دیتی ہے (*IJMA*)۔ عملی طور پر ، شیعہ تشریحات قرآنی سچ کے مجسموں کے طور پر اماموں کی پابندی کو تقویت دیتے ہیں ، جبکہ سنی ریڈنگ کلام پاک اور روایت کی اجتماعی پابندی پر زور دیتی ہے۔ تاہم ، دونوں روایات الٰہی رہنمائی کو اندرونی بنانے کے لئے اخلاقی لازمی طور پر متحرک ہوجاتی ہیں ، اور اس سے بچنے کو ایک روحانی بیماری کے طور پر دیکھتے ہیں جس کے ساتھ ہی اسکیوٹولوجیکل نتائج ہوتے ہیں۔ اس طرح کے تجزیے سے یہ واضح ہوتا ہے کہ مشترکہ قرآنی اصولوں کو روایتی تاریخی تجربات میں جڑے ہوئے مذہبی عینک کے ذریعے فلٹر کیا جاتا ہے۔
11.summary: Classical Shia exegetes, drawing from the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, emphasize that "it" (referenced in the verse) pertains to the "dhikr" or divine reminder mentioned earlier in the surah, understood as the Quranic message and the prophetic legacy upheld by the Imams. In Surah Al-A'laa (87:11), Allah states: *"Wa yatajannabuha al-ashqa"* ("But the wretched one will avoid it"), referring to those who turn away from divine guidance and reminders. This verse contrasts with the preceding one (verse 10), which mentions *"al-atqa"* (the God-conscious) who readily heed Allah’s message. The term *"al-ashqa"* (the wretched) derives from *"shaqawah"* (misery), indicating a soul entrenched in spiritual poverty and rebellion. Imam Ali (as) states, "The Quran is Allah’s rope; whoever holds fast to it is guided to Paradise, and whoever abandons it falls into Hell" (*Nahj al-Balagha*). " Avoiding Allah’s reminders isn’t merely a historical error but a daily choice with eternal consequences.
11.layer2short: In Surah Al-A'laa (87:11), the phrase "وَيَتَجَنَّبُهَا ٱلْأَشْقَى" ("But the wretched one will avoid it") presents a profound theological dichotomy between those who heed divine guidance and those who reject it. Classical Shia exegetes, drawing from the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, emphasize that "it" (referenced in the verse) pertains to the "dhikr" or divine reminder mentioned earlier in the surah, understood as the Quranic message and the prophetic legacy upheld by the Imams. Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* explains that the "wretched" (al-ashqa) are those whose souls are corrupted by arrogance and disbelief, causing them to actively evade truth. This evasion is not passive ignorance but a willful rejection rooted in spiritual blindness, as noted by Imam Jafar al-Sadiq in narrations cited by scholars like Al-Kulayni.

12.layer1:
In Surah Al-A'laa, verse 12 warns of a profound spiritual reality: *"The one who will burn in the Greatest Fire" (alladhi yasla al-nar al-kubra)*. This verse forms part of a Meccan revelation emphasizing divine justice, resurrection, and the eternal consequences of human choices. The *al-nar al-kubra* (Greatest Fire) represents the ultimate destination for those who persistently reject truth, oppress others, and corrupt their souls through arrogance and heedlessness. Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, highlights that this Fire transcends physical torment—it symbolizes the soul’s anguish when separated from Allah’s mercy due to willful disobedience and denial of His signs.

The term *yasla* (to burn) conveys intense, inescapable suffering, contrasting with the ease granted to the righteous (mentioned in subsequent verses). Historically, this Meccan surah aimed to awaken the early Muslim community and their opponents to the Day of Judgment’s inevitability, urging self-purification (*tazkiyah*) and alignment with divine guidance. Shia narrations link rejection of the Ahlul Bayt’s leadership (wilayah) to spiritual ruin, as their teachings embody the Quran’s truths. Imam Ali emphasized that hellfire is "surrounded by desires" people recklessly indulge in—a warning against prioritizing worldly cravings over eternal principles.

Today, this verse calls Muslims to reflect on their spiritual state and societal responsibilities. It challenges us to avoid the "fire" of greed, injustice, and moral decay by upholding Quranic values and the Ahlul Bayt’s ethical framework. Practically, this means resisting oppression, fostering justice, and nurturing taqwa (God-consciousness) in personal and communal life. By internalizing the Quran’s warnings and the Imams’ guidance, believers can purify their hearts, align their actions with divine truth, and seek protection from the *al-nar al-kubra* through sincere faith and righteous deeds.
12.layer2:
In Surah Al-A'laa (87:12), the phrase "who will burn in the greatest Fire" (alladhī yaṣlā al-nār al-kubrā) is interpreted by classical Shia scholars as a reference to the ultimate punishment reserved for those who obstinately reject divine truth and oppose the ontological purpose of creation. The term "al-nār al-kubrā" (the greatest Fire) is distinguished from other descriptions of hellfire in the Quran, emphasizing both the severity of the punishment and the spiritual magnitude of the transgression. As explained in Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan*, this Fire represents the culmination of divine justice, where the intensity of punishment corresponds to the depth of one’s rebellion against God’s guidance and the wilful denial of His signs.

Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* contextualizes this verse within the Shia understanding of *ma‘rifa* (divine recognition), noting that the "greatest Fire" awaits those who reject the *walaya* (spiritual authority) of the Ahl al-Bayt after having received clear knowledge of their status. This aligns with narrations from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, who taught that the Fire’s "greatness" pertains not merely to physical torment but to the existential anguish of being severed from the source of divine mercy embodied in the Prophet’s progeny. The verse thus underscores the Shia theological principle that eternal punishment is intrinsically linked to the conscious rejection of truth (*juhūd*), rather than mere ignorance.

Classical commentaries connect this verse to the broader Shia jurisprudential emphasis on *amr bi-l-ma‘ruf* (enjoining good), as the failure to uphold this duty—particularly regarding the recognition of the Imams—constitutes a spiritual failure warranting severe consequences. The "greatest Fire" serves as a sobering reminder of the cosmic accountability embedded in Islamic ontology, where human choices resonate eternally in the framework of divine justice.
12.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-A’laa’s depiction of the “greatest Fire” (an-nar al-kubra) is interpreted through both metaphysical and existential lenses. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, frames this verse as a warning against spiritual entropy—emphasizing that the “Fire” symbolizes the culmination of persistent rejection of divine truth, not merely physical punishment. This aligns with the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings on the soul’s accountability, where the intensity of the Fire reflects the gravity of moral and ethical failures in life.  

Modern scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this imagery to contemporary crises, arguing that environmental destruction and social inequity mirror the “burning” consequences of human greed and neglect. The “greatest Fire” becomes a metaphor for self-inflicted catastrophes, from climate collapse to systemic oppression, urging societies to align with Quranic principles of stewardship (khilafa) and justice. Philosophically, thinkers such as Dr. Reza Shah-Kazemi contextualize the verse within existential risk theory, where humanity’s unchecked hubris—whether in AI, warfare, or consumerism—threatens to ignite collective ruin.  

Interfaith dialogues, particularly with Christian eschatology and Buddhist teachings on suffering (dukkha), highlight shared concerns about ethical responsibility. The verse’s universality resonates in multicultural contexts, inviting reflection on how “burning” manifests as alienation, ecological grief, or societal fragmentation. For Shia communities, this verse reinforces Imam Ali’s call to “know the self” as a safeguard against inner and outer disintegration—a timeless message revitalized by modern challenges. Ultimately, the “greatest Fire” challenges humanity to choose between self-destruction and transformative renewal, guided by divine wisdom.
12.layer4:
The verse's mention of "the greatest Fire" is illuminated by the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (as) as a profound spiritual reality beyond mere physical punishment. Imam Ali (as) states in *Nahj al-Balagha*: "The hottest fire is the burning of the heart separated from its Beloved." This "Beloved" refers to the divine light of Wilayah – the spiritual guardianship embodied in the Prophet (pbuh) and his purified progeny. The Ahlul Bayt (as) teach that the true magnitude of this Fire lies in the soul's deprivation from the radiance of divine guidance.

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (as) explains: "The greatest Fire is the fire ignited by ignorance of the Imam of one's time. Whoever dies without recognizing his Imam dies the death of ignorance." This establishes that rejection of Imamah – the divinely appointed leadership – creates an existential darkness more agonizing than any worldly flame. Lady Fatimah (as) warns in her famous sermon: "The fire of those who oppose us burns in their own breasts," emphasizing that spiritual torment begins in this life through alienation from truth.

Practically, the Ahlul Bayt guide us to extinguish this inner fire through conscious attachment to their teachings. Reciting Ziyarat Ashura daily, as Imam Baqir (as) advised, becomes a "coolness for the believing heart" against the flames of error. Regular reflection on Imam Ali's (as) counsel to "make your tongue moist with remembrance of Allah" through dhikr creates spiritual moisture to quench destructive fires. True protection lies in transforming our inner state through love for the Fourteen Luminaries (as), whose light dispels all darkness. As Imam Sajjad (as) teaches in *Sahifa Sajjadiyya*: "O Allah! Make me among those whose hearts you have tested for faith through the love of Muhammad's household.
